headline: Functionland Targets Cloud Subscriptions as DePIN Storage War Heats Up
subtitle: With FxFiles live on iOS and a benchmark challenge to IPFS, Functionland is staking its claim in a decentralized storage market analysts say could reach $3.5 trillion by 2028.
briefing: Functionland's most consequential recent move was the February launch of FxFiles on iOS — a consumer-facing application that lets iPhone users replace paid cloud subscriptions with self-sovereign, node-backed storage. The release arrives at an inflection point for the broader DePIN sector. <cite index="10-13,10-14">In 2026, the sector's focus has shifted strictly to fundamentals: network revenue, utilization rates, and paying customers, with the combined DePIN market cap exceeding $10 billion as of late January.</cite> Functionland's 900-node network remains modest next to incumbents — <cite index="6-20">Storj, for instance, counts over 20,000 storage nodes across more than 100 countries.</cite> But the company is competing on a different axis: speed. Its published Fula benchmark claims to outperform IPFS, a credible target given that <cite index="26-17,26-18,26-19">IPFS I/O performance is heavily affected by access patterns, and experimental studies reveal that both resolving and downloading operations can become bottlenecks.</cite> The competitive landscape above is also shifting fast. <cite index="14-9">In January 2026, Filecoin launched its Onchain Cloud mainnet, transforming the network from a cold storage archive into programmable decentralized cloud infrastructure aimed at AI workloads.</cite> For Functionland, the strategic window is clear: <cite index="2-10">Flexera's 2025 State of the Cloud report found that 84% of respondents cite managing cloud spend as their top cloud challenge</cite> — precisely the pain point FxFiles and the Fula network are engineered to address. Watch for whether Functionland can convert its iOS launch and benchmark momentum into measurable node growth and $FULA token utility.
